headline: GM (NYSE:GM) Profit Margin Drop Reinforces Value-Focused Narrative Despite Deep Discount to Fair Value
summary: General Motors (GM) posted a net profit margin of 3.5%, down notably from 6.2% the previous year, as profitability took a hit. While GM’s earnings are projected to grow, the pace is expected to be just 0.5% per year, significantly lagging both the US market average of 15.5% and the auto industry’s typical trajectory. With shares trading at $66.62, below an estimated fair value of $86.07, GM’s value appeal stands out even as shrinking margins and slower growth cast a shadow over investor...

headline: Wall Street ends mixed as earnings lift the Dow
summary:
STORY: U.S. stocks closed mixed, with the Dow adding nearly half a percent, the S&P 500 flat and the Nasdaq dipping marginally.

Third-quarter earnings season has shifted into overdrive, with corporate giants such as General Motors, GE Aerospace, 3M and Coca-Cola posting generally upbeat results.

But with major U.S. stock indexes hovering near record highs and valuations stretched, upbeat results alone could prove insufficient to sustain investor risk appetite, says Richard Mullen, CEO and founder of Pallas Capital Advisors.

"I think that the majority of the returns have been put in for the market this year. I wouldn't expect a further prolific advancement to the upside. I think we could stay status quo or trade sideways, perhaps down a little bit. [FLASH] Earnings, again, is going to drive the markets, but I also think that a lot of the price appreciation has baked in the earnings that we're seeing right now."

Among those that reported results, General Motors lifted its forecast and tempered its anticipated tariff hit, sending shares up nearly 15%.

Coca-Cola shares gained more than 4% after solid consumer demand drove its better-than-expected results.

Manufacturer 3M advanced more than 7.5% after hiking its full-year forecast, bolstered by its focus on higher margin products and cost controls.

On the flip side, Netflix dropped almost 6% in extended trading after the streaming company missed earnings targets due to an unexpected expense from a dispute with Brazilian tax authorities.

But with major U.S. stock indexes hovering near record highs and valuations stretched, upbeat results alone could prove insufficient to sustain investor risk appetite, says Richard Mullen, CEO and founder of Pallas Capital Advisors.

I think we could stay status quo or trade sideways, perhaps down a little bit. [FLASH] Earnings, again, is going to drive the markets, but I also think that a lot of the price appreciation has baked in the earnings that we're seeing right now."

headline: Heard on the Street Recap: Tarnished Gold
summary: Gold futures plunged. The precious metal had its worst trading day in over a decade. Front-month futures traded 5.7% lower to $4,087 per troy ounce. Silver futures fell 7.2%. It wasn’t entirely clear what triggered the decline.

content.title: Heard on the Street Recap: Tarnished Gold
content.summary: Gold futures plunged. The precious metal had its worst trading day in over a decade. Front-month futures traded 5.7% lower to $4,087 per troy ounce. Silver futures fell 7.2%. It wasn’t entirely clear what triggered the decline.

headline: GM Soars Most in Five Years as Truck Demand Spurs Outlook Boost
summary: Six months after pulling its full-year forecast over uncertainty about the Trump administration’s tariffs, GM said Tuesday it now expects to make $12 billion to $13 billion in adjusted earnings before interest and taxes in 2025 — up from a previous range of $10 billion to $12.5 billion it had affirmed in July.  The improved outlook comes as GM is seeing a jump in sales of high-margin, gas-powered SUVs and trucks partly enabled by moves to ease federal emissions rules.  In a letter to shareholders and on a conference call with analysts, Chief Executive Officer Mary Barra thanked President Donald Trump for extending through 2030 a tariff discount on some imports for carmakers that produce and sell completed automobiles in the US.

content.title: GM Soars Most in Five Years as Truck Demand Spurs Outlook Boost
content.summary: Six months after pulling its full-year forecast over uncertainty about the Trump administration’s tariffs, GM said Tuesday it now expects to make $12 billion to $13 billion in adjusted earnings before interest and taxes in 2025 — up from a previous range of $10 billion to $12.5 billion it had affirmed in July.  The improved outlook comes as GM is seeing a jump in sales of high-margin, gas-powered SUVs and trucks partly enabled by moves to ease federal emissions rules.  In a letter to shareholders and on a conference call with analysts, Chief Executive Officer Mary Barra thanked President Donald Trump for extending through 2030 a tariff discount on some imports for carmakers that produce and sell completed automobiles in the US.

headline: GM cuts EV production in Canada, cites Trump backpedal
summary:
General Motors said Tuesday it was ending production of an electric vehicle at a plant in Canada, a further blow to the country's auto sector tied to President Donald Trump's opposition to EVs.
Canada's auto industry has been battered by Trump's global tariffs on foreign-made vehicles, but GM's decision to stop production of an EV van in Ingersoll — about 160 kilometers (99 miles) west of Toronto — was not directly linked to the trade war.GM made a specialized zero-emission delivery van at the I

headline: American Corporations Are Crushing It. This Stock Rally Isn’t Just About Tech.
summary: U.S. companies are stampeding through the third-quarter earnings season, setting up the stock market for an end-of-year rally that could defy the risks from tariffs, inflation, and the trade war with China that still overshadow the world’s biggest economy.  Tesla  and  International Business Machines  will take the baton on Wednesday, providing September quarter updates that effectively fire the starting pistol on an important series of earnings from the tech sector that probably will dictate market performance over the coming weeks.

headline: General Motors lifts forecast as tariff outlook improves, shares surge
summary:
STORY: Shares of General Motors surged more than 15% Tuesday morning after the company raised is profit outlook, putting them on track for their biggest single day jump in six years.

The automaker says the impact of U.S. President Donald Trump’s tariffs on its business has been less than expected.

GM also said it is experiencing lighter losses on electric cars, as it unwinds massive bets it made on the technology.

CEO Mary Barra told investors in a letter that, quote, "It is now clear that near-term EV (electric vehicle) adoption will be lower than planned," citing changing regulations. "By acting swiftly and decisively to address overcapacity, we expect to reduce EV losses in 2026 and beyond.”

Though she added the vehicles remain its “North Star.”

GM’s quarterly adjusted earnings per share fell but topped expectations. 

Revenue marginally declined from a year earlier.

Still, GM's results could be hampered by supply chain disruptions, additional EV charges and increased warranty costs.

U.S. car sales have stayed strong despite uncertainty around tariffs, rising 6% in the third quarter. 

While automakers have largely avoided raising sticker prices to offset their tariff costs, American car shoppers have continued to opt for pricier models and added features.

Automakers have also been ramping up U.S. investments to help deal with Trump’s tariffs. 

GM announced in June that it would invest $4 billion at three U.S. facilities in Michigan, Kansas, and Tennessee. 

The automaker has previously imported about half of the vehicles it sells in the U.S., mainly from Mexico and South Korea.

GM’s quarterly adjusted earnings per share fell but topped expectations. 

Revenue marginally declined from a year earlier.

Still, GM's results could be hampered by supply chain disruptions, additional EV charges and increased warranty costs.

U.S. car sales have stayed strong despite uncertainty around tariffs, rising 6% in the third quarter. 

While automakers have largely avoided raising sticker prices to offset their tariff costs, American car shoppers have continued to opt for pricier models and added features.

The automaker has previously imported about half of the vehicles it sells in the U.S., mainly from Mexico and South Korea.

headline: GM proving more than capable of mitigating 2025 tariff risks
summary: General Motors (GM) stock is up by as much as 15% on Tuesday after the American automaker raised its full-year guidance as it now expects a reduced impact from President Trump's tariffs, between $3.5 billion to $4.5 billion. Citi Research Managing Director Michael Ward details the amount of risk GM leadership was able to mitigate. Also catch GM CFO Paul A. Jacobson discuss navigating the "tariff burden" with Yahoo Finance executive editor Brian Sozzi. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Market Catalysts.

content.title: GM proving more than capable of mitigating 2025 tariff risks
content.description:
General Motors (GM) stock is up by as much as 15% on Tuesday after the American automaker raised its full-year guidance as it now expects a reduced impact from President Trump's tariffs, between $3.5 billion to $4.5 billion.

Citi Research Managing Director Michael Ward details the amount of risk GM leadership was able to mitigate. Also catch GM CFO Paul A. Jacobson discuss navigating the "tariff burden" with Yahoo Finance executive editor Brian Sozzi.

To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Market Catalysts.
content.summary: General Motors (GM) stock is up by as much as 15% on Tuesday after the American automaker raised its full-year guidance as it now expects a reduced impact from President Trump's tariffs, between $3.5 billion to $4.5 billion. Citi Research Managing Director Michael Ward details the amount of risk GM leadership was able to mitigate. Also catch GM CFO Paul A. Jacobson discuss navigating the "tariff burden" with Yahoo Finance executive editor Brian Sozzi. headline: GM Is Dealing With Tariffs and an Evolving EV Business. Its Stock Is Jumping.
summary: The car manufacturer is ahead of schedule in adapting to tariffs, analysts with Citi said.
